utterances: No, I mean, the sort of number of phone calls we received once the game started.

Alone, it will be very difficult if not impossible for either to compete with the companies I mentioned.

The big unknown remains where President-elect Donald Trump falls on the issue.

Now a moment away from politics and into the world of Dr. Seuss.
Long before he became a bestselling children's book author, Theodore Geisel created a series of sculptures he called his unorthodox taxidermy.
He used real horns, beaks and antlers to fashion whimsical creatures like the ones that would later populate his books.
A traveling show of replicas has landed at a gallery in Long Island, Jeff Lunden decided to check it out and report back in verse.
When Dr. Seuss was 3 or 2, his family lived by the zoo.
And as he lay in bed at night, the sounds filled him with pure delight.
At night, he can hear the tigers roar and the elephants bellow and so forth, and he was always drawing animals.
Jeff Schuffman reps the Seuss estate and says the doctor's dad was great.

His father was in charge of the zoo, and when Seuss moved to New York City, his father started sending him various beaks and horns and antlers of animals that had met their natural demise for him to create something with.
And then he decided to turn them into the collection of unorthodox taxidermy as what he thought they'd be reincarnated as.
And, oh, the creatures on the wall are not like ones you've seen at all.
On the Sea-Going Dilemma Fish, we have the horns or antlers from a caribou.

From the Goo-Goo-Eyed Tasmanian Wolghast, we have rams' horn - and then the Semi-normal - you can imagine what he looks like - Green-lidded - in terms of his eyelids - Fawn so that you have deer antlers and just hysterical, joyous look on this Semi-normal Green-lidded Fawn's face.
But Schuffman's favorite of the group has eyes that shine and ears that droop.
We have Anthony Drexel Goldfarb with his inquisitive look and forlorn smile.
Actually, the original was constructed with rabbit ears.
And then he would take, you know, papier-mache and clay and mount it on these wood mounts to create this incredible, very unique and actually limited collection.
He only made 17 sculptures that we're aware of.
Still, since the ones the doctor made are delicate and somewhat frayed, the animals that go on tour are copies, as we said before.
For kids who see this silly show, they do not care or do not know, like Alexandra Thompson, who adores a fish that's red not blue with razor teeth and pointy snout.
She loves it.
She could almost shout.
The Sludge Tarpon.
And what is it about the Sludge Tarpon that you really like?
It looked weird (laughter) - its nose.
It kind of reminds me of a swordfish.
And if you think there's nothing worse than missing seeing these in person and you're fond of things bizarre, go to org.npr.
And when you get there, you will see some photos and some history.
Prepare to be amused and stunned and smile.
I did, and I'm Jeff Lunden.
It can be difficult to study the effects of legalizing marijuana.
And now, as many states are making marijuana more available, there's new research from - surprise - the Netherlands that might address an important question.
NPR's social science correspondent Shankar Vedantam is here to explain.
Welcome.
Hi, Ari.
Tell us about this Dutch study.
Well, the Dutch study was addressing a perennial problem that researchers have in studying marijuana laws, Ari.
From a research perspective, what you really want to study the effect of a law is to have the law selectively apply to only some people.
So if half the people in a city were given access to pot while the other half were not, you could compare the two groups and study the effects that marijuana has.
Now, in most places, you don't have that kind of control group.
Either all adults have legal access or no adults have access.
The new Dutch study found a way out of the problem.
It utilized a natural experiment in the city of Maastricht.
And what exactly did they do?
How did they get some people who used marijuana and some who couldn't?
Polly Boudreaux, of the St. Bernard Parish Council, thanks very much for speaking with us.
That's Andre Brent(ph).
He oversees the pools here at the John Argue(ph) Swim Stadium in Exposition Park just south of downtown LA.
Brent is tall, lean and very firm with his young charges during their swim tests.
Right now he's deciding which pool a young girl can go in.
Deep water, intermediate, or the shallow splash pool.
As stronger swimmers do laps in the lanes next to her, she dog paddles for a few moments before Brent gently gives his verdict.
Okay, listen up.
I'm going to send you back around there.
You've got to practice a little bit more, okay.
Now what I want you to do when you get a chance, have your parents sign you for our swim lessons and we'll show you how to pass this, alright?
This stadium was built for the 1984 Olympics and it still hosts several swim competitions a year.
But most of the time it's a public pool serving many neighborhoods that have few pools or inadequate ones.
It's part of a cooperative outreach program that hopes to teach these children, virtually all of them black and Hispanic, to swim.
Brent says that's important so splashers can become swimmers.
You get a lot of the kids who think they can swim, like they want to get in this deep water over here.
We tell them, You've got to be able to pass the swim test.
And they really can't swim, and once they decide to get out there, you know, they have a problem with their stroke mechanics.
They think they're Superman, and they're not.
It's a serious safety issue.
The Centers for Disease Control reports accidental drowning is the second leading cause of death for children from 1 to 14, and black children run the highest risk of all.
Dr. Julie Gilchrist(ph) is a CDC epidemiologist.
